title: 114_hr5879
content: MODIFICATIONS OF CREDIT FOR PRODUCTION FROM ADVANCED NUCLEAR POWER FACILITIES. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allocate unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation to facilities placed in service before December 31, 2020. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allocate unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation to facilities placed in service before December 31, 2020. The allocation prioritizes facilities based on their service date and nameplate capacity. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allocates unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation to facilities based on service date and nameplate capacity. The excess capacity limitation is calculated as 6,000 megawatts minus the aggregate amount allocated before January 1, 2021, minus any unused allocation. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allocates unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation to facilities based on service date and nameplate capacity. The excess capacity limitation is calculated as 6,000 megawatts minus the aggregate amount allocated before January 1, 2021, minus any unused allocation. In case of any unutilized national megawatt capacity limitation allocated by the Secretary, it will be treated in the same manner as an allocation of national megawatt capacity limitation, and subsection (d)(1)(B) shall not apply to any facility receiving such allocation. Additionally, Section 45J of the Code is amended to include a new subsection allowing for the transfer of credit by certain public entities. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the transfer of credit by certain public entities under Section 45J. Qualified public entities can elect to transfer credits to eligible project partners for a taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows qualified public entities to transfer credits to eligible project partners for a taxable year. If an entity elects to transfer credits, the eligible project partner will be treated as the taxpayer for the credit. The term 'public entity' refers to government entities, mutual or cooperative electric companies, and not-for-profit electric utilities that have received a loan under the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. An 'eligible project partner' is any person involved in designing or constructing an advanced nuclear power facility. An 'eligible project partner' for an advanced nuclear power facility includes those involved in design, construction, providing the nuclear steam supply system, and supplying nuclear fuel. The credit under subsection (a) applies to the advanced nuclear power facility, including those involved in providing nuclear fuel or having an ownership interest in the facility. Special rules apply for partnerships where a qualified public entity is treated as the taxpayer. The credit under subsection (a) applies to partnerships, with a qualified public entity treated as the taxpayer for their distributive share of the credit. Any partner of the partnership is considered an eligible project partner for the credit. The credit is taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible entity. The credit is taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner, following an election made under paragraph (1). Any benefit derived from the election is not considered a private business use for the eligible project partner. The credit derived by an eligible project partner in connection with an election under this subsection shall not be considered a private business use. Special rules apply for mutual or cooperative electric companies regarding income received from such elections. Effective dates for treatment of unutilized limitation amounts are specified. The amendment regarding the treatment of unutilized limitation amounts will take effect upon the enactment of the Act, while the transfer of credit by certain public entities will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2016.
